Let $X\subseteq \mathbb{R}^3$ be the set of all points of the shape\[\left( \sum_{n\in A} \frac{1}{n},\sum_{n\in A}\frac{1}{n+1},\sum_{n\in A} \frac{1}{n+2}\right) \]as $A\subseteq\mathbb{N}$ ranges over all infinite sets with $\sum_{n\in A}\frac{1}{n}<\infty$.
Does $X$ contain an open set?



Erd\H{o}s and Straus proved the answer is yes for the 2-dimensional version, where $X\subseteq \mathbb{R}^2$ is the set of\[\left( \sum_{n\in A} \frac{1}{n},\sum_{n\in A}\frac{1}{n+1}\right) \]as $A\subseteq\mathbb{N}$ ranges over all infinite sets with $\sum_{n\in A}\frac{1}{n}<\infty$.

The answer is yes, proved by Kova\v{c} \cite{Ko24}, who constructs an explicit open ball inside the set. Kova\v{c} and Tao \cite{KoTa24} have proved an analogous result for all higher dimensions.




References


[Ko24] Kova\vC, V., On the set of points represented by harmonic subseries. arXiv:2405.07681 (2024).

[KoTa24] Kova\vC, V. and Tao T., On several irrationality problems for Ahmes series. arXiv:2406.17593 (2024).
